title: 114_hr1297
content:
The Act titled "Disaster Response Reform Act of 2015" includes provisions for FEMA disaster assistance to individuals and households, specifically addressing housing units in housing cooperatives. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act defines a housing cooperative as a multi-unit housing project where each dwelling unit is owned by cooperative members through a membership or share interest in a cooperative association. This definition is included in the Act titled "Disaster Response Reform Act of 2015" which provides FEMA disaster assistance to individuals and households. Section 408(c) of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to provide financial assistance for owner-occupied housing units of housing cooperatives on a unit-by-unit basis. Financial assistance is provided for essential living items owned by a housing cooperative in owner-occupied units. The President will establish procedures to ensure prompt restoration of essential services in housing units following a disaster. Financial assistance is provided directly to residents of owner-occupied housing units or housing cooperatives to restore essential living items after a disaster. The President will establish procedures for prompt restoration of essential services in housing units. The amendment applies to major disasters declared by the President under the Stafford Act after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 102. PERSONAL PROPERTY IN BASEMENTS. Section 408(c) of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to provide financial assistance for damaged personal property located in the basement of an owner-occupied private residence in the same manner as personal property in any other part of the residence. The term 'basement' refers to an enclosed area of a dwelling where any part of the exterior wall or concrete floor is below grade. This definition applies to major disasters declared by the President under the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act. TITLE II--MORTGAGE RELIEF FOR HOMEOWNERS IN DISASTER AREAS

SEC. 201. 90-DAY MORATORIUM ON FORECLOSURES. Applicable agency heads must prohibit foreclosure actions on covered mortgages for 90 days after a disaster declaration. Additional relief measures can be taken as needed.

SEC. 202. REQUIREMENT TO OFFER FORBEARANCE TO AFFECTED HOMEOWNERS. Each applicable agency head must notify mortgagees of covered mortgages in writing within 45 days of a disaster declaration. The notification must include information on eligibility for forbearance relief, requirements for qualification, terms of relief, how to request relief, and the option to agree on forbearance terms. The applicable agency heads must provide guidelines for mortgagors to request forbearance relief on covered mortgages. Mortgagees must promptly determine eligibility and notify the mortgagor in writing of the decision. Contact information for mortgagees regarding additional relief options must also be provided. The mortgagee must offer forbearance to eligible homeowners upon determining their eligibility, along with providing details of the offer, expiration date, acceptance process, and the option to agree on forbearance terms. The mortgagee must offer forbearance to eligible homeowners, including suspension of payments for at least 6 months after a declared disaster. Contact information for additional relief must also be provided. The mortgagee must offer forbearance to eligible homeowners for at least 6 months after a declared disaster. This includes suspending payments and recouping any arrearage by increasing monthly payments by up to 5 percent after the forbearance period. The mortgagee must offer forbearance to eligible homeowners for at least 6 months after a declared disaster, with terms and procedures that comply with guidelines issued by the Secretary and the Director. Additionally, eligible homeowners and mortgagees can agree to other forms or terms of forbearance. The applicable agency head cannot impose limitations on forbearance relief for covered mortgages, including duration, recoupment period, or forgiven principal. Approval from the agency head is not required for mortgagees to offer specific forbearance terms. The agency head cannot impose limitations on forbearance relief terms for covered mortgages. SEC. 203. ENFORCEMENT. The Secretary and Mortgagee Review Board enforce compliance with guidelines under the National Housing Act. Violations can lead to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac restrictions. SEC. 204. DEFINITIONS. For the purposes of this title, the term "applicable agency head" refers to the Secretary for certain mortgages and the Director for others. A "covered mortgage" is a mortgage secured by a one- to four-family dwelling that is the mortgagor's principal residence and located in an area declared a major disaster area. The term "Director" refers to the Director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency. An "eligible homeowner" is a mortgagor under a covered mortgage who experienced a disruption in income due to a major disaster. The term "mortgagee" refers to the original lender under a covered mortgage and any affiliates, agents, subsidiaries, successors, or assignees of the lender, as well as subsequent purchasers, trustees, or transferees of the mortgage or credit instrument. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. SEC. 205. GUIDELINES. The Secretary and the Director will issue regulations within 30 days of the enactment of this Act.
